channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nuclear Talks Will Confront Iran’s Future Capability to Enrich Uranium
item.description: American negotiators say the key is to leave Iran with a face-saving nuclear structure but one small enough to overcome Congressional objections.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Uruguayan Leader Meets With Obama to Talk Trade and Human Rights
item.description: President José Mujica’s visit to the White House came as the South American country seeks new markets for its commodities exports.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Armed Police Begin Antiterrorism Patrols in Beijing
item.description: Beijing has begun special armed patrols in the city, with as many as 13 paramilitary police officers deployed in each of 150 patrol vehicles in an effort to deter terrorist attacks and “mass incidents,” according to multiple Chinese news reports.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Members of the Special Weapons and Tactics team walking past an armored vehicle during an antiterrorism drill in Beijing.

item.title: Authorities in Spain Make Arrests in Fatal Shooting of Politician
item.description: Isabel Carrasco, the head of the provincial council in León, was shot at least three times as she crossed a bridge near her home.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: Provincial Council Leader Shot
item.description: A regional politician from Spain’s governing Popular Party was shot dead in the northern city of León on Monday, prompting the country’s main parties to suspend campaigning.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: World Briefing: Nominee for Egypt Ambassador Post
item.description: The White House moved Monday to fill the long vacant post of the United States ambassador to Egypt by nominating Robert Stephen Beecroft, a career diplomat.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Attack on Former Official Fails
item.description: Eleven people have been confirmed dead and 20 others wounded after a car bomb exploded on Monday at a cafe frequented by government officials in the town of Baidoa, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: A Death Draws Attention to Afghan Police Methods
item.description: There are persistent reports of innocent people being tortured and killed by the police in Kandahar, creating a backlash that local people say has fed support for the Taliban.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: At Least 14 Die as Migrant Boat Headed for Italy Sinks off Libyan Coast
item.description: Italian officials would not estimate the number of people who were still missing, but at least 200 were rescued from the Mediterranean Sea.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Negligence Charges Brought in Quebec Derailment and Fire
item.description: The railway and three employees have been charged in the accident, which killed 47 people and burned much of a town last July.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Russia Keeps Its Distance After Ukraine Secession Referendums
item.description: Instead, the Kremlin used the results, which indicated overwhelming support for secession from Kiev, to press for some manner of negotiated autonomy.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Alexander Malyhin, the chief of the commission that organized the referendum, spoke with journalists on Monday in Luhansk.

item.title: In One Eastern City, Ukrainians Find Battle Hits Too Close to Home
item.description: Many near misses from high-explosive mortar rounds have shown the possibility that conditions are in place for pulling the country toward civil war.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yevgeny Kharkovsky escaped being wounded on Sunday when mortar rounds landed around his home in Slovyansk, Ukraine.

item.title: Russia Vows ‘Harsh’ Response to Airspace Snub and to Raid of a Delegates’ Jet
item.description: The plane carrying a group of delegates was turned back by both Ukraine and Romania, and was grounded in Moldova and raided by the local police.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Book Reveals Wider Net of U.S. Spying on Envoys
item.description: The book, by Glenn Greenwald, mentions one incident where Susan E. Rice asked the N.S.A. for help during negotiations with the United Nations Security Council on sanctions against Iran.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Markha Valley Journal: Hikers Spread Democracy in India
item.description: Voting ended Monday in the largest election in history, and the sheer logistics of getting ballots to more than 800 million registered voters was daunting.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Election workers in the Leh District of India checked voting machines last week before leaving for polling stations.

item.title: Support for E.U. Improves, Poll Finds
item.description: But the Pew survey also shows that the project for European integration, conceived more than six decades ago, is seen by many as a symbol of unwelcome meddling and mismanagement.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Kerry to Meet Palestinian Leader in First Exchange Since Peace Talks
item.description: The gathering will take place as Secretary of State John Kerry travels to London this week for meetings on the Syria crisis and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Nigerian Girls Seen in Video From Militants
item.description: If genuine, the video would be the first public glimpse of the girls since they were seized on April 14 from a school in Nigeria’s far northeast.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: A screengrab from a video released by Boko Haram claiming to show the missing girls.

item.title: Qaeda Affiliate Steps Up Video Propaganda Push
item.description: Militants are seeking to capitalize on growing anger over the killings of civilians in drone strikes.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By SAEED AL BATATI and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A representative of a local Qaeda affiliate interviewed men in Shabwa Province, Yemen, in a video posted on YouTube.

item.title: Samsung Leader Stable After Heart Attack
item.description: Lee Kun-hee, 72, has previously been treated for lung cancer and pneumonia, and his latest health problem will almost certainly renew calls for a concrete succession plan.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT and BRIAN X. CHEN
item.media:description: The chairman of Samsung Electronics, Lee Kun-hee, with his daughter Lee Boo-jin, in 2013.

item.title: After Forming Deep Roots in U.S., Man Discovers He Isn’t a Citizen
item.description: Mario Hernandez’s discovery, after nearly 50 years in the United States, that he is not a citizen shows how federal bureaucracies can stumble when it comes to immigration status.
item.dc:creator: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mario Hernandez, in his backyard in Tallahassee, Fla., came to the United States as a Cuban refugee in 1965 but only recently discovered that he never became a United States citizen.

item.title: Scientists Warn of Rising Oceans From Polar Melt
item.description: The depletion of large parts of the ice sheet in West Antarctica is almost certainly unstoppable, with global warming accelerating the disintegration, two groups of scientists reported Monday.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS and KENNETH CHANG
item.media:description: Various measurements have captured the West Antarctic ice sheet changing very rapidly in the region where it flows into the Amundsen Sea.

item.title: Indian Court Says Forced Marital Sex Is Not Rape
item.description: The ruling by a Delhi judge came in a case in which a woman accused a man of drugging her, abducting her, taking her to Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh, to register their marriage, and then raping her.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: Taliban Wage Deadly Attacks in 3 Afghan Provinces
item.description: At least 11 were killed in the attacks, a reminder that as the last Western troops withdraw, the Afghan forces will be hard-pressed just to hold ground.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: China and Vietnam at Impasse Over Rig in South China Sea
item.description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said the two countries had “14 communications” last week, but diplomats in Beijing said they knew of no substantive talks.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
